author: A_Brickset_user
title: Look Sir, DROID
review:
This set is wicked and is was the first set I got C-3PO and R2 in. I liked the set but I relised there isn't much you can do with it. It can be used to recreate the scene at the beginning of episode 4 on Tatooine combined with Mos Eisley Catina and the Millennium Falcon.
Pluses:
*R2
*3PO
*Good for combining with other episode 4 tatooine sets

Minus:
If your like me I now have 4 3PO's and 3 R2's.
The interior lacks of detail.
Overall it is a cool set and if you want to get 3PO and R2 cheap I recommend this set to you.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Not my kind of set!
review:
This is a fine set, but it has nothing valued in it. The escape pod is by far the best thing. It is round and looks good. I hate the way C-3P0 looks, I always have. The R2-D2 is fine just like any other one. I must say that this would be alot better if it had a Sandtrooper on a dewback. 
I really think they should make a lego Jawa desert walker!!!!

author: A_Brickset_user
title: R2D2!
review: I've bought this set for half prize and was very Happy with it. It has My Favorite R2D2 and the other nice droid C3po. The pod has nice pieces But I stil don't know how to open it without breaking it. Nice way to get the figs.

author: mrmitch
title: Must have R2 D2 and C 3PO
review: I do not own alot of Star Wars sets but this one was impossible to pass up. I love the Robots and needed them in my collection. The capsule is kind of unique but the mini figures were my reason for obtaining this set.

author: legolord909
title: Gotta Love C-3!
review: I think this is a nice set.  Not the best, but nice.  When I got the set I thought it would take two seconds to build.  But actually, it took quite a while.  And that's not because there were a lot of pieces, it's because it kept falling apart.  The curved pieces on the pod are very nice, but they do fall off if you're not careful.  But in fairness, the minifigures are great.  You get C-3P0 which you gotta love and you get the classic R-2.  Overall, a nice little set with a pod that looks pretty good when it's completed.  4/5

author: Leggodt94
title: What do you mean it's 'boring'?
review: I mean sure it's small, but it is a part of the classic film. I mean how are you supposed to reinact the droid escape scene without the droid escape set? For its standards, I think it is a great set and should be appreciated more.

author: hustla187
title: "Over HEERRRRRRRREE!" -C3PO
review: This is a really good set. You get the droid duo of C3PO and R2-D2. My first C3PO minifig came from this set which made me happier. The escape pod is pretty good to fit two droids. This is a fantastic set and is a must own.

author: disneyman626
title: Back in the Day!
review: Now a days, this set might not seem like much, but when it was released in 2001 this was a great set. It had one of the first C-3PO minifigures and you got an R2-D2 figure without having to pay an arm and a leg. I don't know why everyone is critical of this set, but you have to look at it from the viewpoint of early Lego Star Wars!

author: Gus_263
title: C3PO and R2 D2!
review: This is a small set of star wars, that remember one of the firsts scenes of the first movie, two droids arriving on tatooine in a capsule. The details of the set are cool, like the head of C3PO, different in comparision with the normal heads, and of R2 D2, made easily. The building included is only the capsule where the droid escaped. This have simple details like the printed images on it, but the upper part remembers in the movie. It don't have much playability due to the size, but is eay put the droids in the capsule, and it is a feature to this set without much additions. The minifigures are cool, the  capsule is good builted and it still playable, too have useful pieces. I rate this set 5/5.

author: general_veers
title: Small, but a decent set
review:
This is a hard set to rate, as it is so small and has hardly any minifigs

Pros- 
Cheap
C-3PO
R2-D2
Good detail on the big white bits

Cons-
To small (It could include more minifigs and models- Jawas, Sandtroopers, Dewbacks)
Interior needs to be more detailed

Minifigs-
C-3PO- Good detail
R2-D2- Again, good detail

Overall 7/10

author: AFOSL
title: A Nice Little Set For The Collector
review:
Droid Escape is one of those Lego kits that has a charm of it's own despite it's short comings.  It has a lot of the hallmarks of many of the early Star Wars sets, and I am a little surprised to see this kit was released as late as 2001. 
It reminds me of kits such as 7110 Landspeeder released in 1999, and compliments that set nicely.  Both kits contain a similar number of bricks, are quick and easy to build, and are a cheap way to obtain minifigures based on major characters from the Star Wars movie.  Whereas the Landspeeder contained old Ben Kenobi and Luke Skywalker, Droid Escape naturally contains C-3P0 and R2-D2.  This kit marks the fourth appearance of the R2-D2 minifigure, but it is only the second outing for C-3P0.  Threepio was only ever available as part of a much more expensive kit at the time; 7190 Millennium Falcon, released in 2000.  For a child on an allowance or people with a stringent income, unable to afford more expensive sets, Droid Escape would have been a very welcome set indeed, finally bringing the Threepio minifigure within reach of a wider audience.  Both Threepio and Artoo are charming renditions, Threepio in particular being a faithful design, with a new head mould and nicely printed torso with markings front and back.  C-3P0's colour in the early Star Wars sets was of a much lighter colour than later renditions.  Artoo's early design is also different from his new look.  For ten years (1999 - 2009) Artoo's head consisted of a white dome with only the top half being printed accordingly.  This never seemed to matter, as having a Lego rendition of R2-D2 was more important than his design...  Until the new, improved design appeared towards the end of 2008.Whichever way you look at it, having both droids in such an inexpensive kit was a real bonus for any collector.
The pod itself is very simple and, once you subtract the number of elements it takes to build a minifigure, contains a mere 37 pieces.  Even the instruction are simple and are printed on both sides of a single sheet of paper - 13 stages in all, not including the assembly of the droids.  The escape pod consists mostly of four large quarter cylinder pieces, only two of which are printed, which seems a little odd, and perhaps, tight on Lego's part.  The decision not print on all four pieces may have been down to costs or maybe down to overall design, meaning that there is more variety of elements contained in the kit.
Like most of the early Star Wars sets, there are a number of brightly coloured elements used during the construction, but most of these are hidden, and more realistic colours - greys and white - are used on the pod's exterior.  Four small cones are used to simulate directional thrusters - two on top and two at the bottom of the pod, and one large cone piece used underneath the pod as a main thruster or exhaust unit.  Unlike the pod in the movie, there is no window, so the droids are unable to look at the devastation they left behind.  The inside of the pod contains no hidden features, in fact it's completely empty.  This does mean that there is plenty of room for the droids to rattle around in, but a small storage cupboard or some kind of survival kit would have been a nice, if not logical addition to the set.  After all, an escape pod would normally be used by organic life forms, not droids, so should be fitted with such ancillary items.
Overall, 7106 Droid Escape is a nice little set, but seemed to serve no function in it's day other than to get the droids into an inexpensive set so that more people were able to acquire them.  And although based on quite a memorable moment of the film, I can't see the re-enactment of a pod falling through space being of much interest to a child.  Playability, therefore, is minimal.Like the Landspeeder, this set will still interest the serious collector, but may not be much sought after by a child, especially now that the droids are available in so many other sets, and have also been improved upon.  For me, this set is a part of Lego Star Wars history, and my collection just wouldn't be complete without it.

author: Kalhiki
title: A cute little pod
review:
Now, I don't know how much this costs. $10 is the most I'd pay for it if you ask me, but that's even going a bit high.

Building experiece seems pretty easy. I got this a long while ago, so I don't remember much. Let's just say I'm able to build it without the directions.

As for Minifigs goes, you get the droids. These are iconic figures, so I'm not going to go into much depth because mostly everyone should have them. You have C3-PO who looks very close to the movies. He also has a very nice and detailed head mold. R2-D2 is also nice, but he doesn't have the third foot as usual. Despite this he does have nice printed on detailing that is a good representation to how he looked in the movies.

The parts are good. You get the nice rounded wall pieces, and some have printed on detail. Nowadays, we all know it'd probably be a sticker. There are also nice engine pieces and, of course, the droids themselves.

Playability... there isn't much to say. It's a pod, so there isn't much you can do with it without another set (probably the cantina). I have lots of fun with this set mainly because I've memorized how to build it, so I can crash it and make it blow up. But other than that, there isn't much.

Now, whether or not you should get it. You don't have to. If you're a completionist, then yes. If you want the droids, get this because you also get a nice little pod. But I'd say pass on this If you want to get an older Star Wars set...

 

...I, personally, think it's adorable.

author: legostarwarsfan12345
title: C-P3O and R@ always stick together, = )
review:
This is a great set and a great way to get both C-P3O and R2-D2 in a cheap way, you don't have to much and the escape pod is a great feature. 


Pros:
Good pod
C3-PO
R2-D2
Cheap

Cons:
none


 I give this set a 10/10, very cheap and very good.

author: Odeinoichus
title: We Seem to be Made to Suffer, it's Our Lot in Life
review:
Set #7106 Droid Escape: A New Hope time. I picked up this set cheap back in 01 or 02 and I was not dissapointed.

 

Droid Escape is a cheap fun little set that gives you C-3PO and R2-D2, two coveted Mini-Figures in any LEGO Star Wars collection. You also get to build up the escape pod from the Tantive IV. The escape pod doesn't use very many pieces, but it gets the job done of depicting this particular vehicle/vehicle accessory in your LEGO display. It offers up printed pieces instead of stickers for the details and is fairly straight forward. Although there isn't much to be done with this set as far as gimmicks are concerned.

 

R2 is R2, the same Astromech pieces we've all come to know are used in his construction. 3PO is not gold, but he is impressive and unique looking and includes a double-sided torso.

 

Overall this set is nice, it's not blow your mind awesome, but it does offer up a cheap alternative to buying the more expensive sets to get the two droids. Of course if you don't have it yet, but already have both droids then there's really little point to adding this set to your display unless you are strongley influenced to be a LEGO Star Wars completist. It is a fun little set, but not necessarily a must have for the more casual LEGO Star Wars fans.

author: Zapp_Brannigan
title: Simple, but detailed
review:
I received this set 12 years ago from a friend. The build was extremely easy and it did not take more than 5 minutes. Once completed, I was actually quite happy with the end result. And for those of you who don't know, this set is from the scene in Star Wars IV: A New Hope, when C-3PO and R2-D2 eject from the Tantive IV and land on Tatooine.

To start off, this set comes with C-3PO and R2-D2. A bulk of the pod is made up of four 4x4x6 quarter circle panels. Two of those panels are detailed to look machine-like, and they are pre-printed elements. The pod has a removable roof to allow you to put both characters inside, and the roof has two small thrusters which propel the pod downwards. The bottom of the pod has two small thrusters and one large thruster which propel the pod upwards.

As a stand alone, this set will become boring very quickly; but it is a nice set to have if you are looking for a C-3PO or R2-D2. It is a ten year old set that you won't miss out on if you don't have it.

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: Very simple...
review:
The Droid Escape set (7106) is a LEGO Starr Wars set which came out in 2000. It comes with 2 minifigs and 45 pieces. This set does include no decals and there're no mistakes in the instructions and no missing pieces.

[img]http://www.klokriecher.de/gallery_pics/l/7106-1.jpg[/img]

Minifigures:

  • C-3PO: C-3PO comes with his basic torso with his cool detailed markings. His torso is double-sided and has the old pearly look.
  • R2-D2: R2 is very basic too. There're some nice markings on the r2 unit.
Droid Escape:

The escape pod looks very simple. The ceiling can be removed and you can put in the minifigs. There's a big engine on the bottom and some engine parts which do swivel. But there're no more features in this model...

Positive:

Minifigures
Great pieces which you can youse for brickfilms or MOC's
Nice starter set
Price
Idea

Negative:

Not so many play features...
Too easy for older LEGO collectors
I don't think that you can attach this model to the Tantive IV set from 2009. I don't have this model yet but after I've seen reviews about this model I'm sure you can't do it...

All in all it's a great set to get and I would highly recommend you to get this model. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure. Here is the link where you can check out the full galery I made for this set on my website: http://www.klokriecher.de

Videos I made of this set:

Stopmotion 1
Stopmotion 2
Review

author: Optimus_Wombat
title: Cute, fun, easy to build
review:
It's a nice basic starter set, especially good for young kids who may just be graduating from Duplo.

There aren't many pieces involved in the build, and although there are other ways to build a circular hull, you're given just four large pieces to form the hull.  As a consequence the model is much more solid (and therefore playable!) than the over-engineered Star Wars models that LEGO has been releasing in recent years.

No stickers is a plus!

author: Max_Rebo
title: two droids in a pod-not really more
review:
This classic droid escape pod is simple designed and has only two minifigues.

 

Pros:

-also today pretty cheap

-two big printed pieces

 

Cons:

-only two figs(there could be stormies,tusken raiders,jawas,etc.)-->bad playability

-no details?

 

 

There´s nothing else to say about this little set.
